results.title: Dry Hands
results.brief_description: An experimental film capturing the atmosphere of emptiness and boredom which is evident at automatic laundrettes. Contrasts the useless but elegant manicured hands with the constant movement of the washing machine agitating and spinning. Shows the people lounging, smoking, watching the machines and drinking “machine made” coffee to while away the time. They are silent and do nothing, appearing bored, listless and sad in this soulless place which seems to reflect much of life in our modern cities today.

results.title: Drunken Master
results.creator_credit: Zhang Quan, Seasonal Film Corporation and Yuen Woo-Ping
results.brief_description: This 1978 Hong Kong film, one of the earliest to star Jackie Chan, highlights the relationship between a student and his martial arts master.

constellations_other.name: Jason Phu and genre-bending kung fu films
constellations_other.description: Analects of Kung Phu work is a philosophical guide to life via martial arts films, drawing on his interest in Vietnamese and Chinese folklore, which inspires many of the films featured in this Constellation.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Zhang Quan, Seasonal Film Corporation and Yuen Woo-Ping
results.description: This 1978 Hong Kong film, one of the earliest to star Jackie Chan, highlights the relationship between a student and his martial arts master. Wong Fei Hung, played by Chan, is a 19th Century folk hero in Chinese culture and cinema, a master of kung fu who fights the injustice of British colonialism (this character would later be portrayed by Jet Li in ‘Once upon a time in China’). Drunken Master finds Wong in his early years as a troublesome fighter who is sent to his uncle, the hard-drinking title character, for instruction in discipline and martial arts. After enduring torturous training, Wong runs away only to encounter some local villains. Being badly beaten, he returns to his uncle who finally trains him in “drunken style” kung fu. Cast includes: Jackie Chan, Simon Yuen and Lam Yin.

results.title: Drunken boat = Bateau ivre
results.creator_credit: Henri Beauvais, Franfilmdis and Alfred Chaumel
results.brief_description: After the poems of J. Arthur Rimbaud and the symphony “Bateau Ivre” by Robert Bergmann. Prelude for two voices Simon Gantillon and the voice of Rimbaud is Jean-Luis Barrault. In French with no English subtitles.

results.title: Drunken angel
results.creator_credit: Toho Kabushiki Kaisha and Akira Kurosawa
results.brief_description: In 1948 the American army of occupation was still in situ in Japan; Toho, one of Japan’s biggest film production houses and producers of the films of Akira Kurosawa, was riven by strikes - the US Army actually dispersed striking union members who had occupied the Toho site. Against such a backdrop, that any film came out of the Toho state is remarkable. That Kurosawa was able to create a contemporary thriller which was allegorical to the condition of the country, a film rich in traditional Japanese imagery and values, highly esteemed by the critics of his own country - is nothing short of miraculous. Toshiro Mifune takes his first lead role in a Kurosawa film (he became a ‘star’ overnight), playing the sleek but sick young gangster who enlists the help of a shabby, alcoholic doctor, the drunken angel of the title. In Japanese with English subtitles.

results.title: Drums of Fu Manchu. Vol. 2
results.creator_credit: Republic Pictures Corporation, William Witney and John English
results.brief_description: Episodes eight to fifteen of this horror/action movie serial. The story line has Fu Manchu (Harry Brandon) in search of the tomb that houses the legendary sceptre of Genghis Khan. His oldest nemesis Sir Nayland Smith (William Royle) stands in his way and creates an adventure that spans from Asia to America. “And with him, comes the thunder of his summons to death -“

results.title: Drums for a holiday
results.creator_credit: Peter Stiles, Anglo-Scottish Pictures and A R Taylor
results.brief_description: This film looks at the Gold Coast (now Ghana), its history, industries and export trade in cotton and cocoa, and social and political life. Half of the world’s cocoa comes from this region, and the harvesting, fermenting, drying, grading according to quality, and selling and shipping of the beans is illustrated. The film records a ceremonial parade to the local Durbar attended by the King of Ashanti, village Chiefs, and British representatives. Commentary by Leo Genn; photography by Stanley Gooze and edited by John Ferris

results.title: Drummer Hoff (K)
results.creator_credit: Weston Woods Studios, William Snyder, Morton Schindel and Gene Deitch
results.brief_description: This film is a lively folk verse about the building of a cannon called the Sultan. Brightly dressed in full uniform, each soldier brings a part of the remarkable machine. Based on the book by Barbara and Ed Emberly.
